definition: Includes the brain and spinal cord. It processes and integrates sensory information and coordinates motor output.
A clear fluid produced by choroid plexuses in the ventricles. It cushions the CNS, circulates nutrients, and removes waste.
The outermost tough connective tissue layer of the meninges that surrounds and protects the brain and spinal cord.
The middle meningeal layer, web-like in structure, with the subarachnoid space containing cerebrospinal fluid.
The thin, delicate innermost layer of the meninges that adheres closely to the brain and spinal cord surfaces.
A fold of dura mater that separates the two cerebral hemispheres in the longitudinal fissure.
Specialized capillaries in the ventricles that filter blood plasma to produce cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
A CSF-filled cavity located between the brainstem and cerebellum, continuous with the central canal of the spinal cord.
Receptor, sensory neuron, interneuron, motor neuron, and effector, forming the neural pathway of a reflex.
A withdrawal reflex that moves a body part away from a painful stimulus, involving flexor muscle activation.
A reflex that involves withdrawal of one limb and extension of the opposite limb to maintain balance.
A mechanism ensuring that agonist muscles contract while antagonist muscles relax during reflex actions.
A deep tendon reflex that tests the C7-C8 spinal nerves by causing contraction of the triceps brachii muscle.
A sensory pathway in the spinal cord that transmits pain, temperature, and crude touch to the brain.

term: Gray Matter of the Spinal Cord
definition: Composed of neuron cell bodies and unmyelinated fibers, involved in integrating sensory and motor signals.
A major nerve of the brachial plexus, providing motor and sensory innervation to parts of the hand and forearm.
Innervates the deltoid and teres minor muscles and provides sensory input from the shoulder region.
Supplies the adductor muscles of the thigh and a portion of the skin on the medial thigh.
A bundle of nerve roots at the lower end of the spinal cord, resembling a horse's tail.
Gray matter contains neuron cell bodies, while white matter consists of myelinated axons for signal transmission.
A widened area of the spinal cord that supplies nerves to the upper limbs.
The largest brain region responsible for higher cognitive functions, sensory perception, and voluntary motor activity.
Connects the brain to the spinal cord and controls vital functions like breathing and heart rate.
Coordinates voluntary movements, posture, and balance by integrating sensory input.
A large bundle of nerve fibers connecting the two cerebral hemispheres for interhemispheric communication.
Involved in voluntary movement, reasoning, planning, and speech production (Broca's area).
Processes sensory input for touch, temperature, and spatial orientation.
Processes auditory information, language comprehension (Wernicke's area), and memory.
The primary visual processing center of the brain.
Subcortical structures involved in regulating voluntary movement and inhibiting unwanted movements.
A network of structures including the hippocampus and amygdala, controlling emotions and memory.
Includes the thalamus and hypothalamus, responsible for sensory relay and homeostasis regulation.
Regulates body temperature, hunger, thirst, sleep-wake cycles, and links the nervous system to the endocrine system.
The primary somatosensory cortex, processing sensory input like touch and pressure.
Large neurons in the cerebral cortex involved in voluntary motor control.
The outer layer of the cerebrum, responsible for processing sensory information, voluntary movement, and cognition.
Refers to the dominance of one cerebral hemisphere for specific functions, such as language in the left hemisphere.
Regulates motor control by facilitating desired movements and inhibiting unwanted ones.

term: Types of Fibers in Spinal Nerves
definition: Include sensory (afferent), motor (efferent), and autonomic fibers for body function regulation.
An area of skin innervated by the sensory fibers of a single spinal nerve.
Controls voluntary movements by innervating skeletal muscles.
Regulates involuntary functions such as heart rate, digestion, and respiration.
Prepares the body for 'fight or flight' responses by increasing heart rate and energy mobilization.
Promotes 'rest and digest' activities by conserving energy and maintaining homeostasis.
Characteristic of the parasympathetic nervous system; extend to ganglia near or within target organs.
Twelve paired nerves that emerge directly from the brain, each with specific sensory or motor functions.
Pressure-sensitive receptors that detect changes in blood pressure.
Specialized cells in the retina (rods and cones) that detect and respond to light stimuli.
Sensory receptors that detect physical changes such as pressure, vibration, and stretch.
The ability of sensory receptors to decrease responsiveness to constant stimuli over time.
Receptors that monitor body position and movement, located in muscles, tendons, and joints.
Stretch receptors in skeletal muscles that initiate reflexes to resist changes in muscle length.
Receptors in tendons that protect against excessive tension by triggering inhibitory reflexes.
The sense of head position relative to gravity, detected by the vestibular system.
The sense of rotational movement, detected by the semicircular canals.
Transmits sensory information related to the sense of smell to the brain.
Transmits visual information from the retina to the brain for processing.
